comments.author: Nick Gregory

comments.text:
Well it wasn't literally unlimited. Not like Prototypes in LM. Group B cars 
had to have 200 road going versions sold. Group B rallying sounds awesome, 
the cars were monsters, those pilots were on of the bravest racing drivers 
of all time. Sadly, the cars were hideously unreliable, and not one fatal 
accindent occured. Also the cost of running these cars and making new parts 
every race was too much for some.
comments.author: harddave90

comments.text:
I dont wanna be a dick, but those cars do reached 250 mph, just google some 
data, you the are the one missinformed. The Sauber C9 is one of those, the 
R92CP topped around 245 mph, at the Group C era, limitations were minimal. 
I just like top speed, but seems great that you are an internet 
psychoanalyst that knows my frustrations :). I like top speed and 
performance, oh yeah, you are an idiot.
comments.author: Kevin Sanchez

comments.text:
I think you may be misinformed--the fastest Group C cars could manage 
roughly 240 mph at the end of the Mulsanne straight--which now has 
chicanes--and was 4 miles long. I could see a Nissan R92CP hitting 255 less 
all downforce-producing parts, but the loss in braking and cornering 
ability would cause lap times to slow drastically. I understand your 
frustration with race cars' top speeds, but it's about the lap times and 
balance of performance between cars, which the regulations help to ensure.
comments.author: 69BlueL88

comments.text:
ive driven the c5r xero competition car 1200 kilos 600bhp on open 
restrictor, only revs to 5700rpm so much torque you can leave it in 4th and 
go round most circuits in the uk,i also drive LMP cars,500kilos but 400bhp 
nissan engines,slicks wings and aero,theres no comparison,an LMP car is up 
2 10 secs a lap quicker but twitchy goin from understeer as you lose the 
aero and go into mechanical grip on slow corners
comments.author: wendy bell

comments.text:
Because of the gearing. There is no point having a top speed of 220mph if 
the straight isn't long enough to achieve that speed. So they decrease the 
gear ratio's to accelerate faster, but run out of revs just before the end 
of the straight. That gives them the best overall lap-time. And you have to 
consider all the downforce generating devices on the car. A road car is a 
lot more slippery because it doesn't have wings and gills everywhere which 
slows it down on the straights.
comments.author: dude2106

comments.text:
Just because they are racing cars does not mean they go unbelievably 
fast... Look at rally cars for example. They accelerate and handle 
brilliantly, but are not actually that fast.
comments.author: Histor Studios

comments.text:
Yeah, Group C cars used to reach 255 mph on the straights, pure raw power.

comments.author: KJV

comments.text:
If you love it...how could you even possibly think that the vette was 
racing a zonda? And I do agree with you to a point. But I think what they 
are trying to do is to keep regulating things so the teams with huge 
budgets don't run away with it, and make competition fair for the teams who 
can't just throw money at a program. As long as the racing is close and 
exciting, which it is in the current GT field in the ALMS, I have no 
problem with regulating the cars as they are right now.
comments.author: Gipsy-Danger

comments.text:
Nice car, but whatever was in front of it, looked like a Zonda R, simply 
destroyed it. That is the problem with these GT3 or GT2 cars; the number of 
limitations of the engine and the rev limiter. If they allow the brands to 
be free and do the car as they please, it would involve more tech on the 
races, push more boundaries and force these brands to really improve the 
cars in all areas. This Vette its just too slow... too limited.
